large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development
Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to welcome children to preK, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (decide, grandmother).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Do you think Alma likes her name?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to draw a self-portrait showing something they like or like to do or something they are known for.
Guide children to think about things they can include in their drawings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What names can you find in your book?
Which character from your book can you pretend to be?
How many numbers do you know?
Draw one of the characters from your book.
Make a drawing of you and a friend.
What letter is at the beginning of your first name?
What can you make out of blocks that reminds you of home?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder building relationships and introduce vocabulary (tell a story, relationships).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Alma and How She Got Her Name .
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children decide whether the pictures show a good relationship or a bad relationship.
Guide children to assess the characteristics of good relationships.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What relationships do you notice between the characters in your book?
Can you and a partner act out two people meeting for the first time?
How many different families can you find in your books?
Draw something you did with your family.
What materials can you use to create your family?
What letter is at the beginning of the word family? What other words start with that letter?
Use blocks to make a house for your family.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill, engage children in a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary (travel, city).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking How can we learn about other people?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development
Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review with children how people like to do different things.
Help children act out activities pictured on cards about what some children like to do.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What different things are the people in your book doing?
Pick something you do every day before school and act it out.
Count the number of children who are wearing the same color as you.
Write the first letter of your name. Find out if anyone else has a name that starts with that letter.
Draw a picture showing you and a friend playing your favorite game.
What letter is at the beginning of the word city?
Use blocks to make the first letter of your name.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal. Copyright © 2018 by Juana Martinez-Neal. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I like to . . .
Book:Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about what people like to do, play an alphabet game, and introduce vocabulary words (catch, square).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I like to . . . and Alma and How She Got Her Name .
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of conversational partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development
Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Revisit the square Vocabulary Card with children.
Have children draw squares and then add pictures of things they like to do inside the squares.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Think about the different things the characters in the book like to do.
Can you act out one of your favorite activities?
How many of the things on the I Like to… chart do you and your friends like to do?
Write about your favorite photo from the I Like to... chart.
Draw a picture of something your family likes to do together.
What letter makes the beginning sound in the word like?
Can you build a model of your favorite building in your town?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal. Copyright © 2018 by Juana Martinez-Neal. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary (mountains, just right).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How can learning the story of your name make you feel?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What does your name tell people about you?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about a character with your name, what would the book be about?
Pretend you are meeting someone for the first time. What would you say?
Look around. How many names do you see?
If you could change your name, what would your new name be?
Draw a picture for a friend of things you like.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word mountains? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to make a tall mountain?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal. Copyright © 2018 by Juana Martinez-Neal. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Identify similarities and differences between the self, classmates, and other children, inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Regulate their own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
